content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes provisions for improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, establishing a national hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of end-of-life planning. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in medical records, provide individuals with the opportunity to discuss related issues with a professional, and streamline written requirements. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in medical records and allows providers to honor out-of-state advance directives to the same extent as in-state directives, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include advance directive content in medical records, preempting inconsistent state laws. Medicaid provisions are also updated to emphasize the inclusion of advance directives in a patient's current medical record. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include advance directive content in medical records, preempting inconsistent state laws. Medicaid provisions are updated to emphasize the inclusion of advance directives in a patient's current medical record. The Act also requires providers to offer individuals the opportunity to discuss issues related to the information provided in the advance directive with a trained professional. Additionally, providers must give effect to valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed under state law. The provider must honor valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed under state law. State laws inconsistent with this provision are preempted, but laws providing greater portability or deference to a patient's wishes are not preempted. These amendments apply to provider agreements under title XVIII. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX. The effective dates are specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, not later than 1 year after the enactment of the Act. State plans under title XIX requiring legislation to meet additional requirements will not be considered non-compliant solely for failing to meet these requirements before the specified date. The State plan will not be considered non-compliant with the requirements of the title solely for not meeting additional requirements before the specified date, based on the amendments made by subsection (b). Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. Medicare will cover end-of-life planning consultations as part of an initial preventive physical examination. Medicare will cover end-of-life planning consultations, which involve discussions between a physician and an individual about preparing advance directives, situations where they may be needed, the benefits of a comprehensive end-of-life plan, and how to identify resources for state-specific treatment wishes. The amendments made by this section apply to initial preventive physical examinations furnished on or after January 1, 2009. SEC. 4. NATIONAL INFORMATION HOTLINE FOR END-OF-LIFE DECISIONMAKING AND HOSPICE CARE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a 24-hour toll-free hotline to provide information on advance directives, end-of-life decisionmaking, and hospice care services. SEC. 5. INCREASING AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF END-OF-LIFE PLANNING. Title III of the Public Health Service Act will be amended to emphasize the importance of end-of-life planning. SEC. 5. INCREASING AWARENESS OF END-OF-LIFE PLANNING by adding a new part to the Public Health Service Act to focus on ADVANCE DIRECTIVE PLANNING ISSUES. This includes SEC. 399FF for ADVANCE DIRECTIVE EDUCATION CAMPAIGNS. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for care near the end of life, explain the importance of advance directives, and educate the public about hospice and palliative care. At least 60 percent of funds will be used for grants to public or nonprofit entities for this purpose. The section authorizes $25,000,000 for grants to public or nonprofit entities for conducting education campaigns for a period of 3 years.
